text:
Sport The future of football? MLS announce deal to show regular season games live on Facebook Matches will be produced specifically with mobile devices in mind, allowing supporters to engage directly with the commentary teams Share Reigning MLS Cup holders Seattle Sounders (Photo: Getty) Share Get football   Thank you for subscribing!   
Major League Soccer have announced a deal with Facebook which will see at least 22 games from the 2017 regular season broadcast on the social media channel. 
MLS and Univision Deportes confirmed on Friday a deal to live stream games in English, via the Univision Deportes page. 
The matches will be produced with mobile devices in mind, and will feature Facebook-specific commentators and features allowing viewers to engage directly with the commentary team during games. 
MLS are looking to drive up their social media presence and engagement with supporters, as the league seeks new ways to grow. LA Galaxy defender Ashley Cole (Photo: Getty Images North America) 
“We are committed to serving our passionate fans,” said Gary Stevenson, president and managing director, MLS Business Ventures in a statement. “We are working with all of our partners on making sure our games, and additional content, get to our fans anytime, anywhere, and on any device.” 
The first match to be streamed will be Atlanta United - the new expansion team coached by former Barcelona and Argentina boss Gerardo Martino - against Chicago Fire, on March 18 (9PM GMT). 
MLS will also produce 40 exclusive “Matchday Live” shows on Facebook on match days, featuring highlights and analysis. Seattle Sounders celebrate their MLS Cup final victory over Toronto FC (Photo: Getty) 
“Major League Soccer’s innovative approach to the fan experience has cultivated truly special in-stadium environments, where flag-waving and chant-singing fans come together to passionately support their clubs,” said Dan Reed, Facebook head of global sports partnerships. 
“We’re very excited for MLS and Univision Deportes to bring this same innovative, community-first spirit to the Facebook Live broadcasts of league matches this season. 
It comes with La Liga having already signed up to stream one game a week on the social network, while Mexico’s Liga MX is also signed up.
